metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Mitigating loss of health insurance and means tested benefits in an unconditional cash transfer experiment: Implementation lessons from Stockton's guaranteed income pilot

body_text.text: As the novel coronavirus threatens the health of Americans and the US economy, 2 cash transfers have received broad bipartisan support in both the House and Senate as one 3 method to address the severe financial distress brought on by the pandemic (Grisales, 4 Snell, and Davis, 2020). In March 2020, members of the Republican and Democratic 5 parties introduced cash transfers as part of a coronavirus stimulus package, illustrating 6 that the concept of cash transfers and guaranteed income (GI) programs have moved out 7 of the research space and into the policy conversation (Grunwald, 2020) . Nonetheless, to 8 date, neither the proposed stimulus package nor other GI policy proposals discuss how 9 these influxes of cash will or will not interact with means tested benefits and income 10 thresholds, leaving some households at risk of preserving their financial stability at the 11 expense of their access to health insurance and other benefits (Identifying Author). In the 12 midst of an unprecedented crisis and a surge of GI experiments, the field of public health 13 and allied disciplines are ideally situated to lead the policy community in developing 14 models that assist policy makers in ensuring that cash transfer interventions and GI 15 experiments preserve benefits rather than produce new forms of inequality. This paper 16 uses the loss mitigation strategies and ethical framework employed by the Stockton The concept of combating poverty by providing Americans with a cash transfer or 22 GI based on economic need first entered policy debates in the 1960s (Steensland, 2008) . 23

Recent research demonstrating the efficacy of cash transfers in improving health equity 24 outcomes-from reductions in hospitalization rates (Forget, 2011) , obesity (Lebihan et Given the rise of the gig economy, unemployment risks posed by automation, and the 30 fluctuating nature of waged labor, income volatility-an annual income fluctuation of 31 25% or more already impacting nearly half of the US population (Pew Charitable Trusts, 32 2017)-is likely to continue influencing health outcomes, highlighting the inextricable 33 link between public health and economic stability (Standing, 2011) . In a call to the public 34 health community, Sanjay Basu (2017) identified rising income volatility as a leading 35 preventable threat to public health. GI may be one component of a larger economic 36 justice structure that could smooth this volatility, and the onus for implementation of 37 ethical and just GI models rests on public health and allied disciplines. 38
Philosophical and ethical debate about GI and its interaction with the safety net 39 dates back to the original negative income experiments of the 1960s (Harris, 2017) . 40

Throughout 2019 and early 2020, Andrew Yang popularized a "freedom dividend", 41 providing every American citizen with a $1,000 cash transfer in his bid for the 42 Democratic presidential nomination that would make existing welfare and social program 43 beneficiaries choose between the cash transfer and benefits (Friends of Andrew Yang, 44 2020), leading to a renewed public debate on whether Yang's proposal could lead to 45 more, rather than less, inequality by depriving low-income Americans of targeted support 46 47
little is known about how cash transfers may interact with the social safety net in the US. 48

As demonstrated through the debate around Yang's proposal and concerns around the 49 coronavirus stimulus package (Identifying Author), it is difficult to anticipate the impact 50 and related ethical concerns of unconditional cash transfer programs on benefit recipients. 51

First, depending on recipients' circumstances, GI may contribute to the "benefits 52 cliff," where a small increase in earnings can lead to a reduction in public benefits, such 53 as health insurance, food assistance, and housing support (Dinan, 2007 open-ended entitlements available to all who qualify, others are limited, in part, to 57 program funding or location (US Government Accountability Office, 2017). As a result, 58 decision-making among low-income welfare recipients involves weighing short-term and 59 long-term costs and benefits within these constraints and the availability of other formal 60 and informal resources (Edin and Lein, 1997; Roll and East, 2014; Zippay, 2002) . In 61 particular, social supports provided by informal networks, through both direct (e.g., 62

financial contributions) and indirect (e.g., child care) mechanisms, are used by low-63 income families to "help alleviate the stress of the cliff effect, with tangible resources and 64 reduced isolation" (Roll and East, 2014, p. 185) . 65

In addition, eligibility and income calculations, divergent as they may be, are 66 interpreted and implemented by "street-level bureaucrats," who serve as front-line 67 workers in direct service positions within agencies, lower courts, educational settings, 68 and other government entities (Lipsky, 1980) . Since street-level bureaucrats are those 69 operationalizing policy on a micro-level, they are typically the first ones to interpret and In means tested benefit programs, all clients ought to receive equivalent 77

treatment, yet they are also individuals with unique needs at the mercy of workers 78 interpreting complex rules (Lipsky, 1980) . In an implementation study of public (1) the federal coronavirus cash transfer program which would provide American tax 93 filers earning less than $75,000 ($150,000 joint return) a single payment of $1,200 per 94 individual ($2,400 joint return) and $500 per qualifying dependent, but does not specify 95 how or if this transfer would impact eligibility for existing means tested benefits 96 (Jamerson, Duehren, and Andrews, 2020); (2) proposals which seek to replace existing 97 means tested benefits with a basic GI for all Americans; and (3) the Stockton Plan, 98 described here, which seeks to provide GI alongside existing means tested benefits. 99 (i.e., at least 18 years of age with a current Stockton mailing address) were randomly 140 assigned to one of three groups: treatment (n=125), active control (i.e., participated in all 141 data collection activities; n=200), or passive control (i.e., did not participate in data 142 collection activities but consented to use of administrative data; n=150). The treatment 143 group includes five additional participants to account for medical attrition due to a pre-144 existing condition or a catastrophic medical event that would preclude ongoing 145 participation in research activities. In February 2019, the treatment group began receiving 146 the intervention, an unconditional cash transfer of $500 per month for 18 months on a 147
pre-paid debit card, without work requirements or spending restrictions. All research 148 methodology was approved by the [blinded for review] IRB. 149

The "benefits cliff" is a structural component of many existing social safety net 151 programs that effectively causes resource stagnation or reduction as participants increase 152 income (Dinan, 2007) . Thus, a critical ethical and practical consideration of 153

implementing GI alongside existing means tested benefits is the risk of existing benefit 154 reduction or disqualification. Because the purpose of SEED is testing GI alongside 155 existing safety net benefits, not in place of them, we implemented several loss mitigation 156 steps including a sampling frame without a household-level designee, onboarding of 157 potential recipients that included benefits counseling as a part of informed consent, and 158 intentional human contact between SEED staff and recipients as they navigate the 159 existing benefits structure. excusing GI from income calculations to ensure it wouldn't be counted against recipients' 212 benefits eligibility. There were, however, limits on which benefits waivers could 213

As part of informed consent, potential recipients received a comprehensive 215 overview of the potential impact of GI on other benefits. Table 1 describes benefits (i.e., 216 financial aid, food assistance, health care, housing support) potentially impacted by GI 217 and recommendations that are part of an ongoing exchange between SEED staff, local 218 partners (e.g., the San Joaquin County Human Services Agency, Housing Authority of 219 the County of San Joaquin, legal counsel) and recipients. Those at risk of experiencing 220 any benefit reduction also received a one-page cost-analysis fact sheet that detailed the 221 amount of benefits that could potentially be impacted. At this stage, five recipients opted 222 out of SEED, and other households were randomly selected from the passive control 223 group to take their place. 224

Finally, in the event that recipients do experience a partial or total loss of means 225 In keeping with the project's commitment to agency and self-determination, 265 recipients also communicate regularly with the program office as to whether or not they 266 would like staff to communicate with the caseworkers managing their benefits regarding 267 the amount of money provided through the GI. Additionally, when the 18-month pilot 268 ends, staff will assist recipients who may need to re-apply for benefits, leveraging 269 existing relationships with local agencies to ensure that recipients maintain all benefits 270 for which they are eligible once they are off-boarded from the study. It is essential to consider implementation factors alongside policy to protect GI 286 recipients. As researchers seek to advance knowledge related to GI, tensions around 287 benefit loss may impact research activities that are carried out in a traditionally 288 "distanced" way lacking the human contact noted prior. Investigating innovative 289 solutions responsive to income volatility requires a combination of "on the ground" 290 engagement and self-determination where researchers make place-specific program 291 considerations, recognizing the interaction of their work within the existing benefits 292 structure. They must also engage with "street level bureaucrats" to understand how their 293 programs will be interpreted and treated locally (Lipsky, 2010) and, if possible, advocate 294 for waivers that will ensure no harm comes to recipients. 295

Upholding recipients' ability to make informed decisions regarding their 296 participation remains crucial to this process and is mandated by the professions of public 297 health and social work (NASW, 1994 Recipient does a costanalysis of how much they will lose in SNAP, and then makes a decision to (not) move forward.

Housing assistance for low-income families, the elderly, and persons with disabilities either through governmentowned housing or vouchers to be used in the private market Low risk: Recipient share-of-cost does increase but is reimbursed by the Hold Harmless Fund through a partnership with the local housing authority.
Recipient encouraged to participate, assuming no other benefits concerns.

BIBREF52.title: HIGHLIGHTS • Unconditional cash transfers, universal basic income, and guaranteed income have re-emerged as a potential solution to entrenched economic inequality and income volatility

BIBREF53.title: Methods used within the country's first contemporary guaranteed income experiment in Stockton, CA, are testing how this income can exist alongside existing safety net benefits

FIGREF0.text: Empowerment Demonstration (SEED) as a pilot and policy proof of concept to 18 demonstrate how the new wave of cash transfer policies and GI experiments can preserve 19 existing health insurance and other benefits. 20 BACKGROUND 21

FIGREF1.text: 25 al., 2019), psychological distress (Baird et al., 2013), incidences of psychiatric disorders 26 (Costello et al., 2010) and depression (Powell-Jackson et al, 2016; Yoshikawa et al., 27 2012), to increases in life span (Aizer et al., 2016)-has renewed interest in cash transfers 28 and GI as a means of mitigating the impacts of financial insecurity and income volatility.29

FIGREF2.text: 70 apply emerging policy during the implementation phase of a new program or intervention 71 (Identifying Author; Tummers et. al., 2015). The legal and ethical gap created when 72 introducing new policies or interventions sharply departing from legacy bureaucratic 73 structures can generate tension and uneven programming during implementation, 74 particularly when workers feel caught between competing auspices and codes of ethics 75 (Identifying Author).

FIGREF4.text: 79 programs, Roberta Rehner Iverson (2000) found that "invisible barriers" to 80 implementation, such as faulty policy logic and personnel incompetence might prompt 81 implementation delays and programmatic strains that harm recipients while undermining 82 the efficacy of programming. Often absent from research attention (Rehner Iversen, 83 2000), these barriers can generate cascading effects on program outcomes and produce, 84 rather than eliminate, inequalities (Identifying Author). 85 POLICY LANDSCAPE 86 Given the recent proliferation in GI pilots in the US (Jain Family Institute, 2019), 87 including recent announcements of pilots in Chicago (Chicago Resilient Families Task 88 Force, 2019), Jackson (Economic Security Project, 2019), Philadelphia (Blumgart, 2020), 89 and Newark (Crowe, 2019), it is essential to bring awareness to what, at this point, is 90 essentially a policy and implementation gray space carrying competing sets of mandates 91and ethical dilemmas. At present, the public discourse around GI reflects three options: 92

FIGREF5.text: Option two, espoused by Yang, is predicated on Milton Friedman's ideal GI 100 structure, whereby cash transfers are designed to completely replace all means tested 101 benefits under the auspices of improved government efficiency and enhanced work 102 incentives for recipients (Moffett, 2003). Friedman's proposal was intended to be tested 103 in the Seattle-Denver Income Maintenance Experiment (SIME/DIME), one of the largest 104 negative income experiments of the 1970s. Members of the experimental group already 105 receiving cash welfare were required to choose monthly whether to receive cash benefits 106 from Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) or the negative income tax (US 107 Department of Health and Human Services, 1983). The intended design testing 108 SIME/DIME against existing safety net benefits was upended, as treatment group 109 members receiving AFDC would not sign over to receive the negative income tax 110 without protection of existing benefits, including health insurance, housing vouchers, and 111 subsidized childcare (Mathematica Policy Research, 1983). Thus, a GI option that fails to 112 protect against the detrimental health and financial impacts of benefits loss in the current 113 policy landscape is demonstrably infeasible. 114 Herein, we present option three, the Stockton Plan, which draws on an ethical 115 framework informed by public health and social work codes of ethics, and research 116 informed by Institutional Review Boards (IRBs). This makes SEED the first 117 contemporary pilot to bring the ethical concerns around loss of benefits to the forefront of 118 the GI policy debate, and one that can guide ethical and just implementation of GI. 119 Rather than relying on economic projections, GI pilots are taking place in real time and 120 carry real world impacts for recipients. Thus, there is a clear immediacy for public health 121 and social work professionals to uphold the ethics of the respective professions while 122 producing sound empirical evidence capable of influencing public policy. Moreover, 123 while some developing GI pilots may not be governed by human subject research 124 protections mandated by IRBs, similar ethical measures should be considered to protect 125 GI recipients within the existing policy landscape. This paper demonstrates how SEED 126 used ethical mandates of both public health and social work to attend to ethical conflicts 127 inherent in GI experimentation. We begin by describing the pilot design itself as a rubric 128 and exemplar for discussing how implementation and design decisions such as sampling, 129 recipient onboarding, and democratizing human contact effectively preserved recipient 130 benefits in the existing policy landscape. 131 THE STOCKTON PLAN: RECRUITMENT AND INTERVENTION 132 To understand how GI could exist alongside, and interact with, an existing means 133 tested welfare system, SEED captured a diverse sample of Stockton, California residents 134 recruited from census tracts at or below the City's Area Median Income (AMI) of 135 $46,033 (n=42). We selected a proportion of the population represented in each census 136 tract at random (n=4,200 households) to receive a SEED invitation mailer. After 137 removing duplicate or invalid responses from the mailed invitation (N=27), the final 138 sample at recruitment baseline was 475. Respondents meeting limited inclusion criteria 139

FIGREF6.text: 160 The ethical underpinning for SEED rests on principles within the public health 161 and social work codes of ethics. Specifically, the principles of the ethical practice of 162 public health promote the right and resources to health, recognize both social 163 interdependence and individual rights, and encourage collaborations that build trust and 164 bolster effectiveness (Public Health Leadership Society [PHLS], 2002). Similarly, the 165 ethical principles of social work bid social workers to act honestly and responsibly and 166 promote ethical practices. This includes valuing the dignity and worth of every person by 167 promoting socially responsible self-determination, as well as recognizing the importance 168 of human relationships to enhance both community and individual well-being (National 169 Association of Social Workers [NASW], 1994). The following loss mitigation steps 170 detail implementation and research design decisions that were specifically formulated 171 with attention to ethical practice. 172 LOSS MITIGATION STEPS 173 Sampling Strategy 174 In traditional survey research design, address based samples select a household 175 member a priori, or request that the eldest member of the household, head of household, 176 or household member with the next upcoming birthday respond to the recruitment ask 177 (Battaglia et al., 2008). SEED invitation mailers were not addressed to any one person in 178 the residence typically referred to as the "any adult" approach. While this sampling 179 strategy may be less robust for randomization than a two-stage screener sampling strategy 180 (Battaglia et al., 2008), it represented a critical step in preserving the ethical foundations 181 of the project. 182 Specifically, a key standard of ethical public health practice requires the 183 recognition of both social interdependence and individual rights (PHLS, 2002), and 184 employment of one of the fundamental ethical standards of social work, self-185 determination, requires that social work professionals regard clients as experts on their 186 own lives (NASW, 1994). By addressing the invitation letter to "Resident", the individual 187 or family's right to determine who was best to respond, based on existing relationships 188 and networks within the household, financial need, use of benefits, health status, or other 189 factors, was preserved. For example, if a person receiving Supplemental Nutrition 190 Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits received the invitation mailer, she may have had a 191conversation with her partner about the potential for benefits reduction and the family 192 might have collectively determined her partner as the better fit to participate in the study.

FIGREF7.text: sampling procedures, onboarding into experiments typically represents 195 a hands-off approach. Participants receive introductory materials through mail or email, 196 may attend a single orientation, and have limited human engagement with the individual 197 researchers or program staff. Centering both the right to health and resources outlined by 198 public health practices (PHLS, 2002) and the importance of human relationships 199 highlighted in social work principles (NASW, 1994), SEED invited all members of the 200 treatment condition to attend an individualized onboarding session. These individual 201 meetings not only helped recipients navigate a complex benefits structure and preserve 202 access to means tested programs like health insurance provided through MediCal, but 203 also helped establish rapport and trust between the program and recipient from the outset. 204 During those onboarding meetings, a licensed clinical social worker discussed 205 with the recipient that while GI payments do not exceed the yearly gift tax limit of 206 $15,000 (Department of the Treasury, Internal Revenue Service, 2018), as a pilot GI 207 program, SEED could not guarantee how a front-line caseworker may classify the 208 payment when certifying means tested benefits. Eligibility for benefits that use this same 209 gift criterion carried a low risk of being impacted by GI, but other benefits include gifts 210 as part of eligibility calculations. Where possible, the SEED team pursued waivers 211

FIGREF8.text: tested benefits during program participation, SEED established a Hold Harmless Fund to 226 ensure no recipient is worse off financially as a direct result of receiving GI. Modeled 227 after the hold harmless provision included in the statute for the Alaska Permanent Fund 228 Dividend (Social Security Administration, 2019), this fund provides reimbursement to 229 recipients if they become ineligible for benefits due to receipt of GI. 230Democratizing Human Contact 231Valuing relationships and building trust through collaborations were key 232 components that allowed SEED to democratize human contact at all points in the pilot.233 Reducing friction in the social safety net and the threat automation and artificial 234 intelligence pose for technological unemployment are often cited as rationales for 235 introducing a universal basic income or GI (Goodin, 1992; Walker, 2016). These 236 potential shifts are already present in low-wage retail sectors where automation is 237 eliminating human contact in a variety of transactions previously marked with relational 238 interactions (Hegewisch, Childers, and Hartmann, 2019). Meanwhile, unlike early 239 research around the digital divide citing socio-economic gaps between those with access 240 to technological advances and information technology and those without (Norris, 2001), 241 the drop in the cost of technology coupled with the comparatively expensive nature of 242 human employment is rendering new questions about who is granted access to human 243 contact in their everyday lives and under what terms. As Bowles (2019) argues, "human 244 contact is now a luxury good," whereby those with considerably more capital have the 245 latitude to ensure their children's education, their market transactions, their care work, 246 and medical interactions are laced with relational interactions rather than mediated 247 through screens and artificial intelligence. Part of GI's appeal is its potential to address 248 the threat of technological unemployment through a mechanism that simultaneously 249 reduces the friction of human contact required to maintain large bureaucratic structures 250 governed by means testing. Paradoxically, however, the final critical tier of mitigating 251 benefits loss, upholding ethical principles and ensuring implementation efficiency, rests 252 on the human contact and relationship building between SEED's program staff and the 253 research team. Maintaining intentional recipient engagement while navigating a fluid 254 policy landscape requires relational friction in order to preserve benefits while receiving 255 GI. 256 The intense research activities of SEED, alongside the very human nature of it, 257 have created unique partnerships among the intervention staff, research staff, and 258 recipients. The Stockton-based program officer not only ensures completion of surveys 259 on a monthly basis, but a licensed clinical social worker also checks in on the financial 260 lives and well-being of recipients. As scheduled recertification appointments for housing 261 vouchers or SNAP benefits come about, the program officer and other SEED staff remain 262 in conversation with recipients about how they are choosing to protect limited resources 263 while leveraging the $500.264

FIGREF9.text: demonstrated a relationship between cash transfers and improved health 273 outcomes, but the implications of potentially losing benefits when receiving a cash 274 transfer remain under examined. Researchers operate under ethical mandates to ensure 275 that their work does not produce new inequalities, threaten individual agency, or discredit 276 the field by failing to account for feasibility concerns. While IRBs seek to protect human 277 subjects in research, given the lack of standard benefit eligibility requirements and 278 income calculations, they may fail to realize the potential impact of cash transfers on 279 recipients' overall resources. For pilots that are not governed by these boards, it is even 280 more important that researchers remain proactive to protect recipients by upholding 281 professional practice standards. Both the public health and social work professions are 282 uniquely positioned to conduct research that is empirically and ethically sound. Here, we 283 provide effective practices for mitigating the loss of existing benefits from SEED, one of 284 the first contemporary GI experiments. 285

TABREF1.text: ; PHLS, 2002;Thomas et al., 2002). GI recipients 298 who may have previously experienced long waiting periods for public assistance 299(Seefeldt, 2017) may be reluctant to participate in GI experiments that may jeopardize 300 their existing benefits and require them to repeat onerous applications and processes. At 301 the same time, recipients should be encouraged to consider the costs and benefits of 302 receiving GI to ensure they do not face a penalty for collecting a cash transfer. 303Experiences from SEED can inform other GI pilots being conducted within the 304 context of the US social safety net and in the midst of a pandemic-driven economic crisis 305where cash transfers are being introduced on an unprecedented scale. While the current 306 coronavirus stimulus package proposes a single cash transfer, the scale of the package 307 creates a considerable policy precedent in an era of GI experimentation. The boundaries 308 determining which benefits are preserved and which are left to chance can inform future 309 public health research while offering public health and allied disciplines an opportunity to 310 shape research and policy. 311Table 1.
